title: Towards Atomic-Resolution Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy in an Uncorrected 30kV Scanning Electron Microscope
content: The advent of practical aberration correction can only be described as an era-defining technological and methodological advancement in the field of nanoscience. Modern aberration-corrected electron microscopes now routinely reach deep sub-angstrom level spatial resolution [1], while ultra-high-resolution monochromators, based on closely related electron-optical ‘corrector’ designs, have enabled spectroscopy in the meV regime [2]. One of the most impactful consequences of these developments has been the widespread adoption of low-voltage instruments, which can maintain very high spatial resolutions, even down to 20kV, thanks to their aberration correctors [3] – with the serendipitous and timely ‘discovery’ of 2D materials such as graphene providing the ideal sandbox and test objects for the development of ‘single-atom microscopy’ in these instruments [4].
